case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Elphinstone Spinning and Weaving Mills Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 9, 1955 of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 31/X of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 31/X of 1954.

facts.text: High Court referred two questions under s. 66 of Indian Income-tax Act by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, was referred the following two questions for decision

facts.text: First question: Whether the assessee Company was liable to pay additional income-tax?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee Company was liable to pay additional income-tax ? and If the answer to question No. 1 is in the affirmative,

facts.text: High Court answered first question in the negative and left second question unanswered.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and in the circumstances, left the second question unanswered.

facts.text: Appeal against High Court judgment on certificate granted by it.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against the judgment and order of the High Court on a certificate granted by it.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax is appellant, Elphinstone Spinning and Weaving Mills Co. Ltd. is respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax is the appellant, and the Elphinstone Spinning and Weaving Mills Co. Ltd., Bombay  the assessee Company  is the respondent.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, previous year calendar year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52  the previous year being the calendar year 1950 , the assessee Company

facts.text: Assessee Company incurred loss of Rs. 2,19,848 and not liable to income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: was found to have incurred a loss of Rs. 2,19,848 and was thus adjudged to be number liable to income-tax.

facts.text: Depreciation allowance under Income-tax Act Rs. 7,84,063 converted profit into loss.

anchor.surface_text: In that year, the assessee Company had made profits, but the depreciation allowance under the Income-tax Act came to Rs. 7,84,063, thus companyverting the profit into loss for income-tax purposes.

facts.text: Assessee Company declared dividends of Rs. 3,29,062.

anchor.surface_text: In the same year, the assessee Company declared dividends mounting to Rs. 3,29,062.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer treated dividends as excess dividend and levied additional income-tax Rs. 41,132-12-0 under Paragraph B of Part I of First Schedule to Indian Finance Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer treated this amount as excess dividend and levied additional income-tax as provided in Paragraph B of Part I of the First Schedule to the Indian Finance Act, 1951. This additional income-tax was companyputed to be Rs. 41,132-12-0.

facts.text: Assessee contended not liable to additional income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee Company that it was number liable to pay additional incometax was number accepted by the Tribunal,

facts.text: Tribunal held assessee liable to additional income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: but the High Court, on an examination of the relevant provisions and the scheme of the Indian Income-tax Act and the Finance Act, 1951, held that it was sound.

facts.text: High Court held assessee not liable to additional income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal interpreted the Paragraph to companyer even a case where there was a loss holding that even a loss may be a total income,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 4, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant. A. Palkhivala, S. N. Andley and J. B. Dadachanji, for the respondents and intervener. 1960. May 4.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that assessee not liable.

anchor.surface_text: We do number accept both the arguments, and agree with the High Court in the answer given to the first question.
As pointed out by the High Court, the second question does number survive, after the first question is answered against the Department.

concepts.unlisted_label: Paragraph B Part I First Schedule Finance Act 1951

concepts.interpretation: Charging section imposing tax on total income at rates prescribed by Finance Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the Finance Act prescribes the rates of income-tax by its First, Schedule, and by the seventh subsection of that section provides

concepts.interpretation: Defines total income as per Income-tax Act for application of rates
concepts.unlisted_description: Rates of income-tax and definition of total income

anchor.surface_text: sub-section (1) of section 23A of the Income-tax Act, a rebate shall be allowed at the rate of one anna per rupee on the amount of such excess
has deducted super-tax from the dividends in accordance with the provisions of subsection (3D) or (3E) of section 18 of the Act-
For the purposes of the above proviso, the expression dividend shall have the meaning assigned to it in clause (6A) of section 2 of the Income-tax Act,

concepts.interpretation: Courts must give literal meaning; cannot supply omissions or read words to make statute apply where language fails
concepts.unlisted_description: No intendment; look only at language; courts cannot legislate

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1955,

issues.text: Whether the assessee Company was liable to pay additional income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee Company was liable to pay additional income-tax ? and If the answer to question No. 1 is in the affirmative, whether the levy of the additional income-tax is ultra vires

issues.text: If the answer to question No. 1 is in the affirmative, whether the levy of the additional income-tax is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to question No. 1 is in the affirmative, whether the levy of the additional income-tax is ultra vires The High Court answered the first question in the negative and in the circumstances, left the second question unanswered.

issues.text: Whether Paragraph B of Part I of the First Schedule to the Finance Act, 1951 applies where total income is a loss or negative figure

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal interpreted the Paragraph to cover even a case where there was a loss holding that even a loss may be a total income, because if total income had to be computed in the manner laid down in the Indian Income-tax Act, the total income might, be a negative figure.

issues.text: Whether words such as 'on the total income', 'profits liable to tax' can be ignored as surplusage or drafting error in the proviso
Whether the proviso to Paragraph B constitutes an independent charging section detached from Section 3 of the Income-tax Act
Whether the deeming provision that excess dividend is out of undistributed profits of preceding years creates total income where none exists in the relevant year

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fiction cannot be carried further than the purpose for which it has been put in the statute.

arguments.claim: Assessee not liable to additional income-tax because no taxable income exists and words 'on the total income' do not apply

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the assessee Company was that inasmuch as there was no income at all which was taxable, the words 'on the total income' did not apply to it and no additional income-tax could be charged.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a particular object. We respectfully agree with the learned Chief Justice that though the interpretation we have placed upon the proviso might lead t

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court; no total income means no application of rate

arguments.claim: Paragraph B covers case of loss as loss may be total income (negative figure)

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal interpreted the Paragraph to cover even a case where there was a loss holding that even a loss may be a total income, because if total income had to be computed in the manner laid down in the Indian Income-tax Act, the total income might, be a negative figure.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the case of a companypany which, in respect of its profits liable to tax under the Income-tax A

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court did not accept; Supreme Court agrees loss not total income for tax

arguments.claim: Excess dividends deemed out of undistributed profits of preceding years makes assessee liable

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that inasmuch as excess dividend, were to be deemed to have come out of the undistributed profits of the preceding year or years and such undistributed profits were available, the assessee Company was liable.

arguments.court_reasoning: Fiction limited to purpose; cannot create total income where none exists

arguments.claim: High Court ought to read Paragraph B modified by intention or as independent charging section

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner contends that, the High Court ought to have read the Paragraph B as modified by the intention or to have treated it as an independent charging Section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the companypany for that year reduced by the rate at which rebate, if any, was allowed on the undistributed profits. The companytention of the ass

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability by IT Act s.3; Finance Act only rates; proviso not independent charging

arguments.claim: Words like 'on the total income', 'profits liable to tax' are surplusage or drafting error and can be ignored

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner contends that some of these words may be ignored as being surplusage or a drafting error, and refers to rulings in which such a course was adopted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Strict construction of taxing statutes; cannot supply omissions or legislate

arguments.claim: Proviso imposes tax directly on excess dividend independent of total income

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner, however, relies upon the proviso to Paragraph B of the First Schedule, and says that the tax is imposed on excess dividend and if excess dividend is paid out, the liability to tax must arise.

arguments.court_reasoning: Tax charged on total income per s.3 IT Act; proviso prescribes rates only

arguments.claim: Where total income nil or negative, any dividend paid is excess dividend
arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot have excess over nil; words cease to have meaning without total income

arguments.claim: Interpretation creates anomaly (applies if income Rs.1 but not nil/loss); avoid anomaly
arguments.court_reasoning: Anomalies from language; legislature to fix, not court by implication

arguments.claim: Deeming excess dividend from prior undistributed profits replaces total income for tax
arguments.court_reasoning: Fiction limited to bringing prior profits into previous year; not create total income

arguments.claim: Liability to tax imposed by IT Act s.3 on total income; Finance Act prescribes rates only
Total income means as per IT Act; no income, no tax even for additional
Strict/literal construction for taxing statutes; cannot ignore words or supply omissions
Words inappropriate for loss/negative total income cases

anchor.surface_text: But when the total income is a negative figure and no tax on the total income is levied, the words of the second part of the Paragraph total income, profits liable to tax... cease to have the meaning

Proviso not independent charging section; only varies rates on total income

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fiction cannot be carried further than the purpose for which it has been put in the statute.

holdings.text: The assessee Company was not liable to pay additional income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: We do not accept both the arguments, and agree with the High Court in the answer given to the first question. As pointed out by the High Court, the second question does not survive,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No total income exists as loss after depreciation; tax under s.3 IT Act requires total income; Finance Act proviso cannot apply without it.

holdings.text: The second question does not survive after the first question is answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the High Court, the second question does not survive, after the first question is answered against the Department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditional on affirmative answer to first question, which was negative.

holdings.text: Paragraph B of Part I of First Schedule to Finance Act, 1951 does not apply where total income is a loss or negative figure.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal interpreted the Paragraph to cover even a case where there was a loss holding that even a loss may be a total income, because if total income had to be computed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss not total income for tax purposes; words like 'total income', 'profits liable to tax' cease to have meaning.

holdings.text: Words such as 'on the total income', 'profits liable to tax' cannot be ignored as surplusage or drafting error.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction of taxing statutes; courts cannot supply omissions or legislate by reading in words.

holdings.text: Proviso to Paragraph B does not constitute independent charging section; liability under s.3 IT Act on total income, Finance Act prescribes rates.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 IT Act charging provision; s.2 Finance Act defines total income per IT Act; proviso varies rates only.

holdings.text: Deeming provision that excess dividend is out of undistributed profits of preceding years does not create total income where none exists.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fiction cannot be carried further than the purpose for which it has been put in the statute. The Income-tax Act creates an assessment year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction brings prior profits into previous year only; cannot replace non-existent total income of relevant year for rate application.

holdings.text: Additional income-tax charged on total income; no tax if no total income even if excess dividend paid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso prescribes rates/additional rates on total income; no independent charge on excess dividend.

holdings.text: Courts cannot avoid anomalies by strained construction; legislature must amend if needed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Anomalies arise from language; courts interpret literally, do not legislate.

anchor.surface_text: Curtis v. Stovin  1 . In that case, the words of the statute were It shall be lawful for either party to the action to apply to a judge of the High Court to order such action to be tried in any court in which the action might have been commenced, or in any court convenient thereto

precedents.cited_proposition: Implying words into statute to give sensible meaning consistent with intention, extending 'court' to mean county court

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Teja Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: The above case was applied and followed in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Teja Singh 1 , which is next relied upon. In that case, the construction, if literally made, was apt to make one section nugatory.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Teja Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Avoid construction making section nugatory if possible

precedents.citation: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2

anchor.surface_text: It, however, quoted also the observations of Lord Dunedin in Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  2  that A statute is designed to be workable, and the interpretation thereof by a court should be to secure that object, unless crucial omission or clear direction makes that end unattainable.

precedents.case_name: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Statute designed to be workable; interpret to secure that unless impossible

precedents.citation: Special Commissioners of Income-tax v. Linsleys Ltd.  3

anchor.surface_text: The next case relied upon is Special Commissioners of Income-tax v. Linsleys Ltd.  3 . It dealt with an obvious drafting error. Section 68 2  of the English Finance Act,1952, contained a reference to Paragraph a  of the proviso to sub-s.  2  of s. 262

precedents.case_name: Special Commissioners of Income-tax v. Linsleys Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Ignoring misdescription in brackets as drafting error

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. South Georgia Co. Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: The last case cited is Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. South Georgia Co. Ltd.  1 . The words of a proviso there construed, ran as follows Provided that where the said gross relevant distributions exceed the profits computed without abatement and including franked investment income,

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. South Georgia Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Construction of proviso on excess distributions over nil profits

precedents.citation: The Cape Brandy Syndicate v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, relies upon the observations of Rowlatt, J., in The Cape Brandy Syndicate v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1  to the effect that in a taxing measure one can only look at the language since there is no room for an intendment.

precedents.case_name: The Cape Brandy Syndicate v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: In taxing statutes, look only at language, no room for intendment

precedents.citation: Wolfson v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  2

anchor.surface_text: He also refers to the speech of Lord Simonds in Wolfson v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  2 , where the following passage occurs at p. 169 It was urged that the construction that I favour leaves an easy loophole through which the evasive taxpayer may find escape.

precedents.case_name: Wolfson v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: No strained meaning to words to close loopholes in taxing sections

precedents.citation: McGregor Balfour Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Unless some other amount, not strictly income, is by law deemed to be income  see for example, McGregor Balfour Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1  , we cannot improve the existing law by deeming it to be so by our interpretation.

precedents.case_name: McGregor Balfour Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Example where non-income deemed income by law

precedents.citation: Rajputana Agencies Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was also placed upon Rajputana Agencies Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , but we find nothing there to support the appellants case. Similarly, in McGregor and Balfour Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , the words were held to be apt to impose a charge.

precedents.case_name: Rajputana Agencies Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Calcutta National Bank Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, no useful purpose will be served by referring to those cases mentioned by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Calcutta National Bank Ltd.  1 , where a schedule which went beyond the purpose for which it was enacted was given effect to.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Calcutta National Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Schedules beyond purpose not given effect
